title: Method and process for predicting and analyzing patient cohort response, progression, and survival
abstract: A system and method for analyzing a data store of de-identified patient data to generate one or more dynamic user interfaces usable to predict an expected response of a particular patient population or cohort when provided with a certain treatment. The automated analysis of patterns occurring in patient clinical, molecular, phenotypic, and response data, as facilitated by the various user interfaces, provides an efficient, intuitive way for clinicians to evaluate large data sets to aid in the potential discovery of insights of therapeutic significance.
claims:
1. A method for identifying and separating groups of patients from a cohort of patients based on one or more targets, comprising:
receiving patient information for the cohort of patients;
identifying one or more interactions for each of one or more patients based at least in part on the received patient information;
generating, for the one or more targets at each of the one or more interactions, one or more timeline metrics identifying whether each of the one or more targets occurs within a time period of an occurrence of the interaction;
identifying, for each timeline metric of the one or more timeline metrics, whether a patient may incur one or more status characteristics within the time period;
training a machine learning algorithm or a neural network implemented by a computer system to produce a target prediction model for each of the one or more targets based at least in part on the one or more status characteristics;
generating, by the target prediction model, predictions for each of the one or more status characteristics for the one or more of patients;
associating the predictions with a respective one or more timeline metrics of the one or more timeline metrics;
generating, by the prediction model, a decision tree based on determining a greatest difference between each of the predictions and the timeline metrics, wherein the decision tree comprises a plurality of leaf nodes, each leaf node associated with a respective group of patients of the cohort of patients, each of the groups comprising similarities based at least in part on at least one status characteristic identified from respective branches leading to the leaf node, and wherein fewer than all of the patients in a leaf node satisfy the at least one status characteristic;
providing importance ranks for the at least one status characteristic based on the fewer than all of the patients, wherein the importance ranks are provided without needing to retrain the target prediction model; and
identifying at least one status characteristic for a patient not included in the cohort of patients based on matching the patient with one of the groups of patients associated with one of the plurality of leaf nodes.
2. The method of claim 1, wherein training a prediction model for each of the one or more targets based at least in part on the one or more status characteristics further comprises:
training the prediction model using gradient boosting based at least in part on the one or more status characteristics.
3. The method of claim 1, wherein the patient information includes data relating to each patient's medical history, treatments, and survival.
4. The method of claim 1, wherein an interaction of the one or more interactions comprises at least one of:
a record from a medical history of a patient of the one or more patients,
a record of a diagnosis,
a record of a medication,
a record of a treatment, surgery, therapy, or procedure,
a record of a cancer progression, or
a record of a genetic sequencing.
5. The method of claim 1, wherein the one or more targets include at least one of progression free survival of a patient of the one or more patients or survival of a patient of the one or more patients.
6. The method of claim 1, wherein the time period is measured in at least one of days, months, or years.
7. The method of claim 1, wherein a status characteristic of the one or more status characteristics comprises at least one of:
a prior occurrence of an interaction,
a prior result of a laboratory test,
a future occurrence of an interaction,
a future result of a laboratory test, or
a characteristic that is measured as a unit of ‘time since occurrence’ for prior interactions.
8. The method of claim 1, wherein the one or more status characteristics include forward status characteristics that relate to the patients.
9. The method of claim 8, wherein the forward status characteristics are actionable.
10. The method of claim 9, wherein the actionable forward status characteristics include at least one of: prescribing one or more medications, prescribing a treatment, or sequencing a sample.
11. The method of claim 1, further comprising:
receiving the associated predictions for each patient from the target prediction model;
receiving an anchor point;
identifying one or more subsets of the one or more patients for which predicted targets, at the anchor point, deviate from an observed target occurrence for the cohort of patients; and
transmitting information to a clinician indicating that a particular patient may experience similar results to the one or more of the subsets of patients based at least in part on patient information for the particular patient.
12. The method of claim 11, wherein the anchor point is determined based on an interaction of the one or more interactions, comprising at least one of:
a record from a medical history of a patient of the one or more patients,
a record of a diagnosis,
a record of a medication,
a record of a treatment, surgery, therapy, or procedure,
a record of a cancer progression, or
a record of a genetic sequencing.
13. The method of claim 11, wherein the anchor point is determined based on a status characteristic of the one or more status characteristics, comprising at least one of:
a prior occurrence of an interaction,
a prior result of a laboratory test,
a future occurrence of an interaction,
a future result of a laboratory test, or
a characteristic that is measured as a unit of ‘time since occurrence’ for prior interactions.
14. The method of claim 11, further comprising:
receiving a selection of one or more forward status characteristics.
15. The method of claim 14, wherein the forward status characteristics include one or more of medications, sequencing, or germline sequencing.
16. The method of claim 14, further comprising:
providing the selected one or more forward status characteristics at the anchor point to the target prediction model.
17. The method of claim 14, wherein, for each branch node of the decision tree, a pair of branches extending therefrom are formed based on at least one status characteristic selected from the one or more forward status characteristics.
18. The method of claim 1, wherein all of the patients in a leaf node of the plurality of leaf nodes satisfy at least one status characteristic.
19. The method of claim 1, wherein providing importance ranks further comprises calculating a population mean prediction.
20. The method of claim 19, wherein providing importance ranks further comprises encoding categorical status characteristic levels as a difference between the predicted value and the population mean prediction.
21. The method of claim 20, wherein providing importance ranks further comprises clustering continuous status characteristics.
22. The method of claim 21, wherein providing importance ranks further comprises aggregating an average difference between the predicted value and the population mean prediction per categorical status characteristic level.
23. The method of claim 22, wherein providing importance ranks further comprises, for each status characteristic, assigning an overall status characteristic importance as a frequency-weighted sum of an absolute value of all differences between the predicted value and the population mean prediction.
24. The method of claim 1, wherein generating the decision tree based on determining the greatest difference between each of the predictions and the timeline metrics further comprises:
generating the decision tree until a number of patients in a leaf node of the plurality of leaf nodes is less than a minimum number of patients.
25. The method of claim 1, wherein generating the decision tree based on determining the greatest difference between each of the predictions and the timeline metrics further comprises:
generating the decision tree until a number of levels of the decision tree is equal to a maximum number of levels.
26. A system for identifying and separating groups of patients from a cohort of patients based on one or more targets, comprising:
at least one computer system configured to:
receive patient information for the cohort of patients;
identify one or more interactions for each of one or more patients based at least in part on the received patient information;
generate, for the one or more targets at each of the one or more interactions, one or more timeline metrics identifying whether each of the one or more targets occurs within a time period of an occurrence of the interaction;
identify, for each timeline metric of the one or more timeline metrics, whether a patient may incur one or more status characteristics within the time period;
train a machine learning algorithm or a neural network to produce a target prediction model for each of the one or more targets based at least in part on the one or more status characteristics;
generate, by the target prediction model, predictions for each of the one or more status characteristics for the one or more of patients;
associate the predictions with a respective one or more timeline metrics of the one or more timeline metrics;
generate, by the prediction model, a decision tree based on determining a greatest difference between each of the predictions and the timeline metrics, wherein the decision tree comprises a plurality of leaf nodes, each leaf node associated with a respective group of patients of the cohort of patients, each of the groups comprising similarities based at least in part on at least one status characteristic identified from respective branches leading to the leaf node, and wherein fewer than all of the patients in a leaf node satisfy the at least one status characteristic;
provide importance ranks for the at least one status characteristic based on the fewer than all of the patients, wherein the importance ranks are provided without needing to retrain the target prediction model; and
identify at least one status characteristic for a patient not included in the cohort of patients based on matching the patient with one of the groups of patients associated with one of the plurality of leaf nodes.
27. A computer program product for identifying and separating groups of patients from a cohort of patients based on one or more targets, comprising instructions stored on a non-transitory computer readable medium to cause at least one computer system to:
receive patient information for the cohort of patients;
identify one or more interactions for each of one or more patients based at least in part on the received patient information;
generate, for the one or more targets at each of the one or more interactions, one or more timeline metrics identifying whether each of the one or more targets occurs within a time period of an occurrence of the interaction;
